headline: Former Attorney General Mukasey: Trump's criticism of Sessions is wrong
subHeadline: Trump criticized Sessions for asking the inspector general to investigate potential FISA abuse; former attorney general Michael Mukasey says the IG is the right person for the job.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL MUKASEY, FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.utterance: Good to with you.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What was it like working for President Bush? Did he ever have differences with you? Did he ever publicly say anything bad about you?

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: We had a couple of differences. He never publicly said anything bad about me. We -- whatever differences we had were resolved internally. He was, after all, the president. I lost a couple. I won a couple.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Did they get heated? Did you ever offer to resign?

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: No. No, not nearly.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: Not nearly.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What do you think of this relationship? What is going on here?

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: Look, I'm not -- I'm not an expert on relationships. I'm a lawyer, not a psychologist.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right. But when the president is constantly second-guessing you -- and it might be his right -- it might just still be burnt and angry about the attorney general recusing himself. But it has never, never calmed. And this latest opinion of the president about the way Sessions handled this whole FISA thing, what did you think of that?

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: I think it's wrong.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Who is wrong?

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: The president is wrong. And he doesn't know his own interests.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Explain.

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: The fact is that the I.G. is the person who should investigate this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: The inspector general.

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: Yes, the inspector general is the person who should investigate this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Even though the president says, oh, that's an Obama guy.

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: Obama guy, my foot. He was there in the George W. Bush administration. He was an Obama appointee, but he's straight as the edge of that table. He's a serious person who investigates things on the merits. And he's investigated other things on the merits that he will conclude when he concludes. Mike Horowitz is a suburb I.G. And I think pretty much every responsible person understands that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: We don't want to get into machinations of...

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: I mean, there's no...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: You don't -- you conduct an investigation of the sort that the president was talking when there's evidence of a crime. There isn't. So, there's no crime to investigate. The I.G. is the person to investigate whether rules and procedures were followed. If he unearths something that smacks of criminality, there will be plenty of time to investigate it.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: OK. Now, let's say he were to leave. That is, Jeff Sessions were to leave, for whatever reason, I can't deal with it, or he's forced out.

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: He has job -- if there's anybody in this world who has job security, he is a person who has job security, because the person who would succeed obviously is Rod Rosenstein.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: And finding a successor, a permanent one, would take a long, long time.

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: I will say.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes. So, the legal fallout from this back and forth, it's generally never advisable to have a public dispute. But do you know at the Justice Department how this is all falling out? Is it a big deal? Are they used to it? What?

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: I don't know for a fact, because I'm not there. I can't imagine that it helps morale to hear about squabbles going on at the department where you work. But I think that the attorney general and the people who work at the department who are serious-minded people do on a daily basis what they should do, which is to keep their heads down, do their jobs, and try to call things the way they see them. And as far as I know, that's what's doing on at the department now. Certainly, that's what Jeff Sessions is doing.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You know, General, I think it's probably one of the toughest Cabinet positions, the attorney general, because, though you're appointed by the president, you serve the people, as do all Cabinet secretaries. But the legal issues come to the fore when the president doesn't think that you're necessarily serving his interests and you're -- you're acting against those interests. How did you handle that? What did you -- just about your day-to-day handling of the job?

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: I handled it by responding and making my case. And, as I said, I won a couple, I a lost a couple. If the president tells you to do something, and it's within the limits of the law, even if you think it's bad policy, you do it, because the president sets policy. If you think it's outside the limits of the law, and the president tells you do it, you say no. And either the president fires you, or you leave. But I don't think that we're at that point with Attorney General Sessions. I think what is going on, of course, is this public criticism, which I don't think is good for anybody.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Why does it continue, though? Would you put up with that, if it were you? Just -- I know it's different with President Bush.

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: I can't...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Would you put up with that?

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: I can't put myself in Jeff Sessions' place in this administration. This is very different from what it was like when I was there. If the president had said something about me in public of the sort that this president has said about Jeff Sessions, it would indicate deep dissatisfaction.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: And you would offer your resignation?

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: Yes, of course. I would have taken it to heart. But it would have been preceded by a great deal that I don't think preceded this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: A lot have said that this president, he is new to the job, doesn't know even about maybe the role of an attorney general, that he was trying to be -- you know, do anything illegal or anything else, but he had read into this loyalty, this is all about loyalty to the president. How do you juggle that as attorney general of the United States, appointed by the president of the United States, serving for the president of the United States, serving the United States?

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: Look, the A.G. is a member of the administration. So, he's got to follow the policy of the administration. But his job is to advise the president on what the limits are of the law, what the law allows at both ends. And then the president makes the choices between those limits. I think President Bush well understood that. And the notion that somehow the A.G. is the president's lawyer is wrong. The president has lawyers. He's got White House counsel.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But on this issue, where -- on this issue, where Sessions decided, I'm going to have an I.G. look into -- handle this whole thing, and the president was ticked off about it, you're saying that Sessions was within his rights, this is the right route to take?

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: It's the right route to take. It's also the correct route to take. It makes a lot...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: As it was back in the very beginning, when he recused himself.

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: That he was in the legal right there, two actions that the president deems unacceptable.

utterances.speaker: MUKASEY
utterances.utterance: Right. The answer to that is, tough.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: OK. Attorney General, very good seeing again. END Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
